text: Content marketers! When presenting to the CEO who is revenue and value-driven (vs the CEO who is brand-driven), how do you make sure you demonstrate that your efforts are linked to the bottom line? I can think of a revenue per subscriber model for instance. But what if you are convinced that you need to drive brand awareness via content, but it may not be linked quite so directly to sales? (e.g blog, educational content, top of the funnel stuff)

text:
For TOFU content, here's what I say:

1) It drives newsletter subscribers. Those subscribers can be nurtured to sign-up for a trial/free with a drip campaign. 

2) Brand awareness directly helps sales people to sell easily. If the prospect already heard about your brand, sales becomes easier. There's some stat on that. You can use it to back it up.

3) Use expert advice. Your CEO maybe convinced if a renowned expert advices them on brand awareness and it's benefits. You can check out Growth Mentor to find the right person for the same.

text:
There are other ways to demonstrate the value of content before the "this person paid us money for the service we're selling". Like Deb said, newsletter signups (or other up-funnel) metrics can show this. It might be helpful if you have any information on customer journey -- maybe someone doesn't convert after visiting one page, but they do after visiting 3 or 4 pages, so the first step is just getting them in the door.

Can you also tie it to other parts of the business? Maybe there's success in retargeting people who visit certain content, or the sales/customer service team finds some blog posts useful when communicating with customers.

"Vanity" metrics like pure traffic numbers or social shares may play a role, but those are obviously going to be a little less directly tied to revenue.

If you don't have anything in-house, try looking for case studies or industry benchmarks or something so you can say "this is WHY we should be doing XYZ" even if you can't prove it out right now.

elements.text:
There are other ways to demonstrate the value of content before the "this person paid us money for the service we're selling". Like Deb said, newsletter signups (or other up-funnel) metrics can show this. It might be helpful if you have any information on customer journey -- maybe someone doesn't convert after visiting one page, but they do after visiting 3 or 4 pages, so the first step is just getting them in the door.

Can you also tie it to other parts of the business? Maybe there's success in retargeting people who visit certain content, or the sales/customer service team finds some blog posts useful when communicating with customers.

"Vanity" metrics like pure traffic numbers or social shares may play a role, but those are obviously going to be a little less directly tied to revenue.

If you don't have anything in-house, try looking for case studies or industry benchmarks or something so you can say "this is WHY we should be doing XYZ" even if you can't prove it out right now.

text:
Oh wow, really appreciate all the responses -- and shameless self-promotion, ha! Let me give a little more context to see if we can dive deeper into this subject. 

My company offers a very niche B2B SaaS product to small businesses that typically have less than ten employees. We currently have around 57k  backlinks -- the majority are from our customers, so they don't have much of a domain authority -- typically sub 30. 

We're discussing whether or not hiring a link building service would make sense to boost some of our better converting content and up our SERPs a bit. We have more than enough backlinks, so we are really just looking for links with serious DA juice. 

My question to Jeremy, Nik, Kane, and anyone else: Since we are in such a niche industry, where would these new links be coming from? And if they are coming from random content exchanges, would they be of value to us? We aren't interested in empty link building just for the sake of links.

Thanks for sharing those sites, Jake and Steven. I’ll check them out.

elements.text:

We're discussing whether or not hiring a link building service would make sense to boost some of our better converting content and up our SERPs a bit. We have more than enough backlinks, so we are really just looking for links with serious DA juice. 

My question to Jeremy, Nik, Kane, and anyone else: Since we are in such a niche industry, where would these new links be coming from? And if they are coming from random content exchanges, would they be of value to us? We aren't interested in empty link building just for the sake of links.

text: Awesome Josh!  I would be focused on getting some high DR/DA links to the specific pages you are looking to boost in SERPs. Mainly from topically relevant content to your SaaS product offering on big blogs in general SaaS and B2B. These would help overall DA/DR, help to improve those specific page rankings, and likely drive some nice referral traffic and signups based on niche fit!

text:
Hello content marketers!
When presenting your tool wishlist to your VP of Marketing, how do you address the ROI the said tool will bring in? I'm a single person content team responsible for global content at the moment and my tool choices are:

1. *Mailshake:* For linkbuilding outreach which at present is manual and takes up a lot of my time. In my opinion the tool will help me scale my link-building efforts substantially.
2. *Clearscope*—Content optimization has helped us a lot, again this requires a lot of work. Since I work a lot with freelancers and guest bloggers I believe it will be a good addition to our stack and will help me refine the optimization process overall.
But again, in my head the ROI is related to the efforts I put in. For example, the more link building campaigns I will run the more ROI it will bring in . So what I state may be arbitrary at this point. So can someone throw more light on it? Thanks heaps :pray::skin-tone-4:

elements.text:
Hello content marketers!
When presenting your tool wishlist to your VP of Marketing, how do you address the ROI the said tool will bring in? I'm a single person content team responsible for global content at the moment and my tool choices are:
Mailshake:
For linkbuilding outreach which at present is manual and takes up a lot of my time. In my opinion the tool will help me scale my link-building efforts substantially.
Clearscope

—Content optimization has helped us a lot, again this requires a lot of work. Since I work a lot with freelancers and guest bloggers I believe it will be a good addition to our stack and will help me refine the optimization process overall.

But again, in my head the ROI is related to the efforts I put in. For example, the more link building campaigns I will run the more ROI it will bring in . So what I state may be arbitrary at this point. So can someone throw more light on it? Thanks heaps

text:
I think it largely depends on what you're currently spending your time on, and what's more relevant to your team/department/company goals going forward (do you need to run more linkbuilding campaigns, or do you need to focus on content creation/optimization).

It's probably worthwhile talking to people who have used those tools (maybe in this community!) to see if they can help benchmark. Like "I was spending X hours doing outreach, and after using Mailshake it went down to Y hours" and that might help you calculate the impact? Or the companies might be able to put you in touch with clients.

text:
One small upside to being a one-person army: every tool can be tracked easily back to your own time.

_"This takes me 12 hours per month without the tool and 2 hours with the tool and it costs $50. Without each of these tools that total $600 per month, we need another PT/FT staffer that costs $3-6k per month."_
